This week's question: Is it better for the environment to dispose of toilet paper in the garbage or in the toilet?
Q. Is it better for the environment to dispose of toilet paper in the garbage or in the toilet?
A. ''It is both practically desirable and ecologically superior to flush it down the toilet,'' said Dr. Allen Hershkowitz, senior scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council.

''In the United States, most sewage and toilet effluent goes either to a septic system or to a sewage treatment plant,'' Dr. Hershkowitz said. ''The biological activity that takes place in those types of facilities decomposes both the organic waste from our bodies and the cellulose that makes up bathroom tissue.

''Conversely, in a landfill, the microbial activity would generate methane gas, a very potent greenhouse gas, not to mention the sanitary risks associated with transporting the waste and the cost of doing so.''

The big ecological problem with toilet paper, in Dr. Hershkowitz's view, is the use of virgin wood rather than recycled paper to make it. He is documenting the flow of fiber from old-growth forests to Canadian mills and says the fiber yield from a ton of waste paper processed to make toilet paper is 85 to 95 percent. If it is made directly from trees, he said, the yield is only 47 percent at most from a ton of hardwood and 43 percent from a ton of softwood.
''There are many brands of post-consumer recycled papers on the market,'' he added.
